articles.headline: As Trump Attacks Georgia Republicans, Party Worries About Senate Races
articles.snippet: Some Republicans in the state fear that the doubt President Trump is sowing about the fairness of the election could depress turnout for the crucial Senate runoff races.
articles.abstract: Some Republicans in the state fear that the doubt President Trump is sowing about the fairness of the election could depress turnout for the crucial Senate runoff races.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s sustained assault on his own party in Georgia, and his repeated claims of election fraud in the state, have intensified worries among Republicans that he could be hurting their ability to win two crucial Senate runoff races next month.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Richard Fausset and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Reinventing Workers for the Post-Covid Economy
articles.snippet: Especially in service industries, old jobs may not be coming back. Training programs are aiming to provide skills for more resilient occupations.
articles.abstract: Especially in service industries, old jobs may not be coming back. Training programs are aiming to provide skills for more resilient occupations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rob Siminoski has been in the theater, in one way or another, since he graduated from college. But after 10 years at the Universal Studios theme park in California, he is only No. 13 on the stage-managing roster. Even if the park, closed since March, reopens some attractions — the WaterWorld stunt show, say, or the Nighttime Lights at Hogwarts Castle — he is unlikely to be among the first to get the call.

articles.headline: In Nagorno-Karabakh Peace Deal, Putin Applied a Deft New Touch
articles.snippet: The iron-fisted tactics used against Georgia and Ukraine seem to have fallen out of favor, replaced by a more subtle blend of soft power and an implicit military threat.
articles.abstract: The iron-fisted tactics used against Georgia and Ukraine seem to have fallen out of favor, replaced by a more subtle blend of soft power and an implicit military threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEPANAKERT, Nagorno-Karabakh — As a dilapidated old van pulled up at a hillside checkpoint, an Azerbaijani soldier inside scrubbed furiously at his fogged-up window, then cast a glowering look at an Armenian standing just a few feet away.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: Goodbye, Blazers; Hello, ‘Coatigans.’ Women Adjust Attire to Work at Home.
articles.snippet: With many professional women working remotely, their notions of work wear have transformed, shaking up businesses that have sought to outfit them for the office.
articles.abstract: With many professional women working remotely, their notions of work wear have transformed, shaking up businesses that have sought to outfit them for the office.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the Before Times, said Rebecca Rittenberg, a 28-year-old who works in advertising sales for Google in New York, one of her favorite parts about going to the office was “showing up in a funky, cool professional outfit.”
